Award.AwardTitle: The cell biology of dynamic and stable intercellular bridges in situ

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Every animal living on Earth is a collection of cells. Our human bodies contain trillions of cells. These cell building blocks are so tiny that over 1500 of them would fill a layer the size of the period at the end of this sentence. However, every animal living on Earth has developed from a single, exceptionally large cell, the egg. This large size is important for early development to proceed properly. We are studying the way in which the mother animal's body creates such big cells. We already know that this requires helper cells to donate their contents to the growing egg, via stable connections. Our ongoing research is on the maintenance of the stability of the window-like connections between helper cells and the egg. We are also studying how the connections are closed at the right time, so that the egg is finally autonomous. Education and outreach activities will include mentoring of K12 teachers, development and engagement of 2nd grade students in development, a math-biology hands on lab for undergraduates, and a novel approach for matching trainees with scientists and engineers. Also included are efforts to broaden participation of URM students and women in science.

The archetypical animal cell has one nucleus. However, in diverse organisms, this rule is broken by tissues such as syncytia. Syncytia are specialized tissues that contain multiple nuclei connected to a common cytoplasm via intercellular bridges. Syncytia are found in diverse contexts such as fruit fly egg chambers, filamentous fungi, mammalian muscle myotubes and plant seeds. In many animals, the egg- and sperm-producing organs are syncytial, and the maintenance of intercellular connections is essential for fertility. Our central aims are to determine the composition, dynamics and regulation of intercellular bridges that connect developing oocytes (egg cells) to a common syncytial cytoplasm. For the propose studies, the model system will be the egg-producing syncytium of the tiny free-living nematod worm, C. elegans. Egg production in the C. elegans syncytial germline is well described genetically and developmentally but has only begun to be explored with cell biology. The small size and transparency of C. elegans make it amenable to quantitative high-resolution in vivo imaging. In addition, quantitative image analysis, photo- and micro-manipulation, biochemistry, reverse genetics and corroborative modeling will be combined to study intercellular connections. C. elegans is highly suitable for dissecting molecular mechanism due to its well-annotated genome and the ease of protein depletion, and genome editing for fluorescent protein tagging. Syncytial intercellular bridges can be thought of as abortive cell division, wherein the cytokinetic ring failed to separate the daughter cells. Therefore, our vast knowledge about how cells pinch in half during cytokinesis has informed hypotheses about the structure and function of intercellular bridges. The high conservation of cell division machinery predicts our findings will be applicable across phylogeny. Furthermore, the conveyor belt-like arrangement of oocyte development from the distal to the proximal gonad will reveal spatio-temporal correlations that predict causal relationships.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our diverse team is working to understand intercellular bridges within multinucleated cells. Known as syncytia, cells with interconnected nuclei can be found in model organisms such as the fruit fly and the popular tiny research nematode C. elegans as well as more complex organisms including humans. In many syncytia, including germlines (or gamete-producing tissues), nuclei are connected to a common cytoplasm via open doorways through which cytoplasm can flow (cytoplasmic bridges). The structure of syncytia, including the properties of the cytoplasmic bridges, has important consequences for fertility. Cytoplasmic bridges allow for communication and coordination among the nuclei that reside there together, incompletely partitioned like horses in barn stalls. For example, in various types of syncytia, cytoplasm must flow out of some stalls and into others to enlarge them. When the oocytes are fully enlarged, the bridges collapse, thus achieving cellularization. If the bridges collapse prematurely, the oocytes do not enlarge properly, and are not viable. Thus, these intercellular bridges must be stable.

We published our findings that in the germline of C. elegans, cytoplasmic bridges are surprisingly dynamic throughout the germline, enlarging and contracting multiple times over their lifetime. We identified two cellular components that limit the contraction of cytoplasmic bridges so that they stay open to allow compartment growth. In the course of that discovery, we found that those same two cellular components that limit contraction are also in the contracting ring that pinches cells in half when they proliferate to make copies of themselves. In another publication, we reported the dialogue among a network cellular components that achieves control of contraction to ensure it is not too powerful. In addition to watching cells through a microscope and making measurements using a computer, we also simulate cellular events using mathematical formulas that describe physically realistic interactions of cellular components. One of the trickiest things to simulate is a collection of molecular motors, which convert chemical energy (from food) to kinetic energy (movement). This funding also supported a publication in which we reported a comparison of different ways to generalize or specify the many working parts of a motor collection. We also tested the effects of depicting different bonds between the motor and its track, since in cells this bond may be like scotch tape, Velcro, or a woven finger trap. This systematic test will help us and other researchers simulating motor collections in many different cellular contexts.

Since cytoplasmic bridges are crucial for animal fertility, our discoveries will, in the long term, inform preventative or therapeutic medicine. Furthermore, findings of how multiple nuclei reside in one cell are relevant to other tissues (including heart muscle cells and certain fungi) with syncytial architecture. The cellular components whose roles we defined act in myriad other contexts including cell movement and internal delivery systems. Importantly, “basic” research aimed at defining the workings of the natural world will always enrich humanity by deepening our understanding in general, and we can almost never predict how and when our findings will directly serve human health and society.

While conducting our discovery-based research, we place significant emphasis on outreach to a variety of audiences throughout the course of this research. Each summer, a K-12 teacher spent 3 weeks participating in our research. These teachers took their experience back to the classroom and relayed their new knowledge and enthusiasm to their pupils. In addition, the PI visited kindergarten and 2nd grade classrooms to teach children about embryonic development using playdough or simple pieces of paper, when the lesson went virtual. This activity was developed according to established teaching goals and with the school’s science specialist. At UNC, we held speed-dating like events in which biologists could meet and cultivate collaborations with physicists, statisticians, and mathematicians. We held a monthly Mathematical Biology seminar series for interdisciplinary researchers at UNC to present their work to a diverse audience.

In sum, our interdisciplinary approaches have produced several published scientific discoveries, trained scientists at a wide range of career stages and in different disciplines.
